desc: CUL3 encodes a component of the E3-ubiquitin ligase complex, which covalently attaches ubiquitin to target identified proteins for subsequent target degradation by the 26S proteasome (PMID: 15071497). Proteins containing the BTB protein-protein interaction domain recruit degradation targets to the CUL3-containing E3-ubiquitin ligase complex for degradation (PMID: 17120193). CUL3 is also involved in the maturation of endosomes associated with lysosomal degradation, and depletion of CUL3 has been shown to impair endolysosomal trafficking (PMID: 22219362). Mutations in CUL3 are also associated with type II pseudohpoaldosteronism (PMID: 23689903). A prominent BTB-containing protein is KEAP1, which recruits the oxidative-stress signaling factor, NRF2, to the CUL3-containing E3-ubiquitin ligase complex for degradation. Mutations in NRF2, KEAP1, and CUL3 have been shown to disrupt the degradation of KEAP1, and subsequently up-regulate the oxidative stress response via KEAP1 and NRF2 and enhance survival of the tumor (PMID: 19321346, 19638449, 23365135).
articles/0/title: Cul3 overexpression depletes Nrf2 in breast cancer and is associated with sensitivity to carcinogens, to oxidative stress, and to chemotherapy.
articles/1/title: Born to bind: the BTB protein-protein interaction domain.
articles/1/journal: BioEssays : news and reviews in molecular, cellular and developmental biology
articles/2/title: CUL3 gene analysis enables early intervention for pediatric pseudohypoaldosteronism type II in infancy.
articles/3/title: CUL3 and NRF2 mutations confer an NRF2 activation phenotype in a sporadic form of papillary renal cell carcinoma.
articles/4/title: Cullin-based ubiquitin ligases: Cul3-BTB complexes join the family.
articles/5/journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
articles/6/title: NRF2 and KEAP1 mutations: permanent activation of an adaptive response in cancer.

desc: CUL3 is a component of an E3-ubiquitin ligase complex that targets proteins for degradation. Mutation of CUL3 disrupt regulation of KEAP1 and NRF2 and promote tumor survival.
